content.webTitle: Wakenhyrst by Michelle Paver review – dark goings-on in the Fens

fields.headline: Wakenhyrst by Michelle Paver review – dark goings-on in the Fens
fields.bodyText: A highly successful children’s author, Michelle Paver actually began by writing novels for adults and has hollowed out a niche for herself in gothic stories for grownups, set at the beginning of the 20th century. Wakenhyrst fits into her oeuvre perfectly, with its atmospheric tale of Maud Stearne, the reclusive occupant of Wake’s End, a dilapidated house in the Fens. Going back to Maud’s childhood at the turn of the last century, Paver weaves an enjoyably creepy plot concerning dark goings-on in the marshes. What’s particularly engaging is the way she shows us, from a child’s point of view, how the adults use both religion and superstition as a means to control others and to limit knowledge that might empower those they hold down. Yet it is Maud’s father’s disdain for women that causes him to dangerously underestimate his beleaguered daughter’s agency. He is gradually, and very satisfyingly, shown to be his own worst enemy. Deceptively breezy storytelling combines with increasingly dark themes to great effect. • Wakenhyrst is published by Head of Zeus (RRP £8.99). To order a copy go to guardianbookshop.com. Free UK p&p over £15.
